item.description:
[Eng] Inspired from Knightmare Chess, a french group of Go game created "Tsunami sur le Goban" which plays on a 13x13 board.

It's a card game for two players : During a classic Go game, players can use cards to change some rules, stones placement...


 
 
 
 
 


[French] Inspiré par Tempête sur l'échiquier, le Groupe Auvergnat de Go a imaginé "Tsunami sur le Goban" se jouant sur 13x13.

On joue sur 13x13 avec un jeu de carte qui sert de pioche pour les deux joueurs.

Durant la partie, les joueurs peuvent changer les règles du jeu, modifier le placement des pierres...

item.description:
This is a card game play in turns. In a turn, each player play a card from hand to the 4 row of the card. When a sixth card play to the row, the player who play the sixth card get the first to fifth cards (5 cards) and the sixth card become the new first card of the row. The sum of the victory points (VP) on the 5 cards is the VP for the player. Different cards have different VP value, some positive and some negative.

There are rules to play the card, only higher number card may be place to the cards on the table. If no card can be place, the longest row on the mat will be discard and replace with a new card from the deck.

Play continue until all players play all the cards in the hand (10 cards).

The one with the most VP win.

Component:
80 cards with number from 1 to 80
7 special card (same card back as the number card)
1 rule sheet
1 play mat
A small game box

item.description: Come discover Kotanook forest during deer migration, when predators and prey take on a gruesome battle to survive. One by one, become each of the wild's most legendary animals, such as a grizzly bear, a wolf or a cougar. The "Kotanook" board game is a unique reproduction of a wild environment, where two opponents take turns combining attacks and evasions. Each player leads a small group of animals, each of them with its own specific qualities (speed, strength and dexterity) in order to collect the highest number of points and become master of their territory. A stimulating board game where chance and strategy meet the instincts of the most ferocious beasts!

From the back of the box:
Take a deep breath and dive into fascinating shark-themed card games like Shark's Tooth Rummy, Sink or Swim, and Wild Wobbegong. Want to know which sharks are nocturnal? Which can leap out of the water? Which is known as "white death"? This fact-filled deck turns the world of sharks into games for your brain.

User Summary:
Shark cards are similar to a standard set of playing cards except each of the 4 suits contains 12 cards (rather than 13). Each of the 12 cards contains a picture of a shark and a description.

There are also 12 Challenge Cards that ask players to look for Sharks with particular characteristics.

The game has rules for 5 different games:
Deep Dive (Similar to Go Fish)
Sink or Swim (Similar to Concentration)
Shark's Tooth Rummy (Similar to Gin Rummy)
Wild Wobbegong (Similar to Crazy Eights)
Food Chain (Similar to Solitaire)

A card game for 2-6 dog's best friends.
 Every player is a trainer in large and famous agility school with the goal to fill as many training groups as fast as possible.

During player's turn he/she can perform following activities (in order listed below):

1) Fill one training group
2) Select one action from following list:

- Make a personal offer
- Retrieve dogs from common waiting list
- Close the training group
- Pass – do nothing

Game ends after one player has filled 3 training groups. All players count their victory points from filled training groups, player with the most points will be the winner.

Components:
18 training group cards (with 2, 4 or 6 points - 6 each card)
64 dogs cards (8 different breeds - 8 each card)

A card game based on Nordic Mythology where the players are the Jarls fighting each other in pursuit for prestige.

In Midgard Card Game the players try assemble their military power by making troops (same kind) or batallions (sequences) to conquest domains in the nine worlds connected by Yggdrasil. Each world has his own difficult levels and rewards in gold or victory points. Players should choose from various small victories or few legendary deeds to acumulate more victory points.

Each player has to "open" their tableu based on current world's level of difficult. After that, he/she can use another player's cards to clear his hand. There are Aesir Cards acting as wild cards or special effects used to slow down another Jarls and Elite Cards to speed up the hand management. Gold coins may be used as an currency to influence more warriors (cards) or as end game victory points.

item.description:
SDS Sparekassen published this game, heavily inspired by Matador / Monopoly. It was published at the latest in 1983, but the specific year could not be found.

You try to earn money by building up a business empire with help from SDS Sparekassen.


SDS Sparekassen udgav dette spil, tungt inspireret af Matador/Monopoly. Det blev udgivet senest 1983, men det specifikke årstal kunnet ikke findes.

Du prøver på at tjene så mange penge som muligt, ved at oprette en masse forretninger med hjælp fra SDS Sparekassen.

Conquering Corsairs is a card game in which you take the role of pirates, trying to gain gold and reputation to become the most feared and famous ship to sail the Silver Seas. You will take your ship to strange and dangerous locations, recruit new crew members to your cause, do battle with other pirates, and put plunder in your hold!

During the game, players take different actions during each of the four seasons of a turn. In Spring, you play pirates on to the deck of your ship. They will be needed to attack locations and recruit new shipmates in the following seasons. In Summer, you sail your ship between islands in the Silver Seas and can either try to conquer them or explore new locations, looking for plunder. In Fall, you recruit new pirates, taking them from either common supply piles or a personal supply that only you have access to. In Winter, you can stow treasure (cards) in your hold, that will gain you plunder at the end of the game. The Pirate King is also determined in Winter, based on the prestige that each player has obtained from their locations and any powerful pirates still in play.

item.description:
Cholopoly is a game based on our funny experiences in Peru. Each player will be a car driver. And will be driving through many dangerous streets of Peru in Lima.

You can buy business, escape from thieves, and bribing corrupt police. Face events like inflation, terrorism, mining company strikes, and supports corruption and become the richest one among all players.

There is no place for fair play. Destroy the other businesses, hire thieves and corrupt cops, to steal and bribe the other players.

Appropriate business and foreign characters, accumulate dirty money and become a millionaire, and lose it all from one turn to another.

Do not misunderstand; this is only taken with mockery, you just have a good time with your friends

Cholopoly wishes you a fun and unproductive game.

Cholopoly

Rie, Jode..., Juega

(Spanish version)

Cholopoly es un juego basado en nuestra criollada peruana. Cada jugador será un conductor, manejando por las peligrosas calles de lima en Peru. Comprando negocios, escapando de ladrones, y sobornando policias corruptos. Afronta eventos como inflación, terrorismo, huelgas mineras, y soporta casos de corrupción, e intenta volverte el más rico entre todos los jugadores.

No hay lugar para el juego limpio. Destruye los negocios de otros, contrata ladrones y policías corruptos, para que roben y sobornen a los otros jugadores.

Aprópiate de los negocios y personajes ajenos, acumula dinero corrupto. Conviértete en millonario, y piérdelo todo de un turno a otro.

No malinterpreten, esto es solo tomar con burla algunas situaciones. Y pasar un buen tiempo con tus amigos

Cholopoly les desea un entretenido e improductivo juego.

Cholopoly

Rie, Jode..., Juega

item.description: Time for a magic tournament at Magicstone Castle! In Simsala Hopp, the young player magicians need to use their magic wands to transform frogs into hares while the animals fly through the air – but if they conjure things too freely, they risk sending animals arcing too high and landing outside the castle, and shenanigans like that will cost the magician points. Whoever can transform many frogs into rabbits without being too careless will collect the most tournament chips and win.

Smile and Like It is a family-friendly card game for 3 - 8 players with a unique twist. On your turn, play a card and do what it says, simple as that. Generally the card will instruct you to claim chips (some face up, some face down, all of which have smiley faces of differing levels of happiness on one side) from the center pot, trade chips you've already collected with other players, and so on.

Here's the twist: you don't automatically get to draw a card at the end of your turn. Instead, you have to claim a special "draw" chip (differently colored than all the other chips in the pot) and have it remain in your score pile until your next turn, at which point you can replenish your hand of cards... but that's all you can do on that turn. Of course, there aren't enough draw chips in the pot for everyone.

So the tension builds: how long do you dare wait to take the draw chip? If you run out of cards, you lose chips from your pot to the players seated on either side of you... but if you happen to have a draw chip in your score pile at the end of the game, you take a massive penalty to your final score.

The game comes with three unique methods of scoring right in the box. One scoring system simply gives more points for happier smiley faces (very family friendly), one scores points for sets of different types of smileys (a bit more strategic, but still family friendly), and one uses patterns of smileys printed right on the cards, giving the players another option on how to play a card: playing it as a scoring card by spending the specific pattern of smileys in the score pile (introducing a hand management aspect to the game suitable for more hardcore gamers).

All in all, Smile and Like It is a game that is simple to learn and play, and yet difficult to master in any of its incarnations, making it a game you'll come back to again and again.

In the gripping murder mystery game Die drei ??? und der Feuerdiamant, the player detectives must work together to solve four criminal cases. With suspect cards, clues, hazard cards and alibi cards all at hand, not to mention hazard chips and power tokens, they're fighting against time, meaning that no risk is too large to take as otherwise the game is lost.

Each playing of Die drei ??? und der Feuerdiamant differs, so the game will still be fresh each time. What's more, the game will be available as an app that features great sounds, additional rules and surprise effects to make the game even more exciting.

item.description:
A trivia game with 780 questions and answers.

By turning the colored roulette wheel the children choose the questions for each card. They select one of the answers to score points, in which each answer option is associated with a symbol, and a color.

There are many interesting topics from the fields of history, geography, biology, wildlife, art, music, sports and culture in general etc.

The board game based on the German TVshow with relationship tests.

In the game it is important that the women know their husband well. They compete with other female teammates and put chips for different bets, eg Snacks eating contest or funny dance routines etc. If a bet is successful, the woman receives all applications and thus comes closer to the victory.

The women have to keep a cool head and play good bets. Essential is a good knowledge of the strengths of the man who in turn must show full commitment in the betting order to seal victory. "My husband can" is an ideal party game and suitable for couples or those who want to be there.

Couple with the most points is the winner.

The letter-cards are mixed and dealt 5 cards for each player, the top card of the remaining stack is revealed.
The objective is to get rid of cards.
In turn player can either use his cards to form a word or place the letters on the top cards that they continue the word.
If player can't form a word he draws a new card.
Words score points - the longer words more points - and player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

name.value: Bingo Pocket Cards: Spaß mit englischer Grammatik
Bingo Pocket Cards: Spaß mit Englischen Redewendungen

item.description:
Simple quiz format card game. Distribute the cards amongst the players. Then take turns asking each other questions from the first card. The cards have numerous questions on them, with the answers on the back.

Rules are not clear about how many questions are asked per card. I would suggest just one. If the correct answer is given, the answering player takes the card.

The game proceeds for as long as you want to play or until a pre-set target of correct answers is reached. The player (or team) with the most cards, wins.

The cards all relate to fairly simple English grammar questions.

With over 250 questions and answers about big cities, additional Joker and booster cards that affect the course of the game, provide games and guessing fun with the Giga-effect.

There are questions one side and 4 variants another side of the card. Draw a card, ask a question and read the variants. Who bet the correct answer scores a point.

Winner is the one with the most points after the deck is exhausted.

With over 250 questions and answers about inventions, additional Joker and booster cards that affect the course of the game, provide games and guessing fun with the Giga-effect.

There are questions one side and 4 variants another side of the card. Draw a card, ask a question and read the variants. Who bet the correct answer scores a point.

Winner is the one with the most points after the deck is exhausted.

With over 250 questions and answers about horses, additional Joker and booster cards that affect the course of the game, provide games and guessing fun with the Giga-effect.

There are questions one side and 4 variants another side of the card. Draw a card, ask a question and read the variants. Who bet the correct answer scores a point.

Winner is the one with the most points after the deck is exhausted.

Name translates to 'Highlights of the Game: France', part of a series of such games with different countries being the subject.

This is a game where you can show off your knowledge of France by answering questions on History, Art, Culture, Sport and Food.By answering questions correctly, and with a little luck, you will collect souvenirs of the country.

The game consists of 48 question cards, 30 souvenir cards, one round ard, 1 rules card and 1 pamphlet with informative background information about your holiday destination.

On each card there are questions in 5 categories and each is designated with its own icon and colour. The five categories in full are;
Eten en Drinken (Green) - Eating and Drinking
Geschiedenis (Yellow) - History
Sport, Spel en Vakantie (Orange) - Sport, Games and Holidays
Kunst en Cultuur (Red) - Art and Culture
Stad en Land (Blue) - Cities and Countries

On each card the category questions are in a different order. On the back of each card are the answers. You play in rounds. The Round Card is placed on the bottom of the deck. You start with the first question on the card you have just drawn. If the Round Card is on the top of the deck, you put it back on the bottom and then ask the second question, and so on until 6 rounds have been played. On the question cards there are also commands, recognizable because the icon box is blank. These commands are on the lines of "Change a Souvenir to a different colour, Lose a souvenir, and so on.

The Question reader is the player to the left of the player whose turn it is. If the question is answered correctly, the player receives a souvenir in the same category of the question. If the player answers incorrectly then that player must lose a souvenir (if he has one) in that category. The question card is then placed on the bottom of the stack and the turn passes to the next player in a clockwise direction.

Maximum number Souvenirs
The number of souvenirs that a player may have in a category is a a maximum of '2 players - 3', '3 or 4 players - 2'.. If a player gets a question in the category of which he already has reached the maximum, then he can choose a souvenir of any other category if he answers correctly. At the end of your turn you can exchange any 2 matching souvenir cards for one in any other category.

The winner is the first player to get souvenirs in all 5 categories

Game Description

Zombie Enclave (ZE) is a free, solitaire game of survival on a Earth dominated by Zombies: while designed as a solitaire game you can easily play ZE with two (multiplayer rules are included).

The focus of the game is the Refuge (the Enclave in the game title), the place where you're trying to defend yourself from the zombie attacks, accumulating enough resources in order to gain some additional weeks of life.

You start the game with a very simple, undefended Refuge and then you will have to plan how to protect your Survivors by adding the many "defenses" available. "Defenses" can be holes, wall reinforcements, explosive barrels, traps and so on: the idea is to replicate the full spectrum of iconic scenes seen in the zombie movies. The game sequence can then be summarized as: gain new resources, spend resources to improve your Refuge, wait for the enemy attack.

Zombies will be managed with a "buildup pool": every turn you draw a buildup chit and apply the results (normally new zombies arriving) while an "Attack!" marker will initiate the combat.

During combat the zombies will move from the upper part of the map (the external defenses) toward your Refuge: the Defenses will try to slow and/or damage the zombies but it's up to the Survivors to close the fight.

In terms of rules, the game will include a set of Standard Rules, with basic tasks and a good set of available resources to start with. Several scenarios will make possible a quick start of the game with not only your Refuge, but also an external defensive wall and a bunch of resource points that you can spend during setup to prepare your initial defenses.

Advanced rules will add more details (like Vehicles and Events), and finally the Campaign game will make possible to start really from zero, with just you and Soldier, your invaluable dog.

Bruges in the 15th century – culture and commerce flourish and make the Belgian Hanseatic city into one of the wealthiest cities in Europe.

In Bruges (a.k.a. Brugge or Brügge depending on the country in which you live), players assume the role of merchants who must maintain their relationships with those in power in the city while competing against one another for influence, power, and status. Dramatic events cast their shadows over the city, with players needing to worry about threats to their prosperity from more than just their opponents...

The game includes 165 character cards, with each card having one of five colors. On a turn, a player chooses one of his cards and performs an action, with six different actions being available: Take workers, take money, mitigate a threat, build a canal, build a house, or hire the character depicted on the card. In principle, every card can be used for every action – but the color of the card determines in which areas the actions can be used or the strength of the chosen action, e.g., blue cards provide blue workers and red cards help mitigate red threats. All of the action is geared toward the gathering of prestige, with the most prestigious merchant winning in the end.

item.description:
HOLD THE LINE comes to the wars of Europe in the Age of Reason with FREDERICK’S WAR. When Frederick II led his army into Silesia a long duel began between a still fragile Prussia and the first class power that was Austria. Featured here are eight battles from the fearsome contest: Mollwitz, Choutusitz, Hohenfriedburg, Kesseldorf, Kolin, Leuthen, Hochkirk, and Liegnitz. The game closely aligns with the Hold the Line system, but includes more advanced command rules, more detailed cavalry rules, optional rules for each warring nation’s units, and much more.


The Prussian army is well drilled and led by a bevy of talented generals, including Schwerin, Zieten, Leopold von Dessau, and of course Frederick the Great. The Austrian army is slightly weaker, but is aided by fearsome light infantry units and in later scenarios are led by such capable commanders as Daun and Loudon.
 As Prussia can you humble the Austrians and make your kingdom a first-class power? As Austria can you weather the Prussian storm and halt the first steps towards decline? The enemy approaches, the sound of cannon deafens, men shout commands, smoke fills the air. You must HOLD THE LINE!

For each scenario each player receives a number of command points to activate the units in his army for movement, close assault, and fire combat. Each side also receives a random number of command points for the same, but never knowing how many creating a battle field chaos that makes the game highly replayable. Scenarios take approximately 1 hour to play so you can get in multiple plays in an evening.

item.description:
The Matching Game You'll Flip For!
In this fun matching game for 2-6 players, kids try to be first to get their animals into the barn! Players search their cards to complete an animal image, then use the Barnyard Flipper to reveal the next image to be matched. Play continues until all images have been matched and all animals are back in the barn!

Roll & Play is the first game ever designed specifically for toddlers! To play, simply toss the big plush cube and identify which colored side faces up. Choose a matching color card and perform the simple activity shown. “Make a happy face,” “Moo like a cow” the activities supported by Roll & Play are designed to help your child shine, supporting healthy development and celebrating success! Roll & Play is the ideal way to gently introduce play patterns and rules through a loving, joyful play experience!

As this is a game primarily aimed at the 3-and-under set, the goal of the game is for a personal best of completing activity cards.

item.description:
Los Incognitos: Alien iacta est is a dice game in which the players try to track down as many extraterrestrial time travelers as possible. The players roll their dice as long as it is possible to carry out at least one of four possible actions. Except from storing a maximum of two dice, the players can walk or fly through different eras of human history in search of alien visitors. They receive points for monsters they have marked and also for sites they have explored. After a certain number of rounds, the most successful monster tracker as determined by the number of points wins.

The mechanisms of Los Incognitos: Alien iacta est are based upon those of Expedition Sumatra: Dadu Dadu, but in addition to the different theme, there are new scenarios on bigger boards with optional rule extensions. The game offers four scenarios varying in complexity, each set in another era of human history.

Number 9 (of 12) in the Epoch Manga game series. Bookshelf game based on the comic strips of Fujio Akatsuka. All movement is spin and move. Each player controls a taxi and picks up fares from the train station. Destination and fare collected is determined by a card draw. Opposing players can move police cars when they land on a police icon to impede other players and force them to draw an event card. Event cards are generally misfortunes, but there are occasional good events (tipping customer, a bonus fare, etc). The winner is the player with the most fares collected once the are deck is exhausted. Art on the board, pieces, and cards are a mish mash of characters from Fujio Akatsuka comics.

item.description:
Simple move game for young players. (4-8)
Don't let the little mermaid die of sadness. She is stuck at low tide. Help her find her way through the castle to safety. From Alvin's Vintage Boardgames.

In Whiskey Gulch, players compete with each other to accumulate resources and money in the post-Civil War American West. Each player controls a family that is attempting to increase their holdings through worker placement, politics, and violence. Players interact with each other and the harsh environment of the West in an attempt to become the most powerful family in the town of Whiskey Gulch.

Each turn begins with an Event Card that affects all players. Players then select two action cards and place their workers on their holdings. Then each player reveals an Environment Card that affects them specifically. Actions are then carried out and combat is resolved. To end the turn players gather resources from their property.

Whiskey Gulch has 3 ages that each last 8 turns. Scoring is based on a combination of money, resources, political offices held, and buildings constructed at game end. There are many paths to victory, but only one winner.

Whiskey Gulch is in post production. Release in Q2 2013

A classic game of happy families with a twist, comprising 7 aristocratic animals, each attired in the sartorial splendour of the Victorian era. An exciting game for all the family.

Contents : 42 cards wich combined together, create the seven "Aristo" characters :
- Dog, Cat, Hare, Ferret, Giraffe and Wolf.
Each character is divided into six parts, which when reconstitued forms the word A-R-I-S-T-O.

The seven "Aristo-Animals" come together to form the Aristo'zzle, a tableau in the manner of a jigsaw puzzle.

From 2 players to 6. 
Minimum age 4 years old.

A biathlon-themed roll-and-move trivia game with a dexterity component.

Aim of the game: Be the first to complete the course on the board three times.

How it is played: 
Players take turns rolling the two dice. If their pawn is on a ascending slope space at the beginning of their turn, they roll only one die. They move their pawn according to the die roll. 
If it lands on a grey space, nothing happens. If it lands on a green space, an action card is drawn and the action performed (move pawn backwards/forwards a certain number of spaces, lose a turn etc.). 
If it lands on a yellow space, a question card is drawn and the active player has to answer a biathlon-related question. If they succeed, their pawn advances five spaces. If they fail, they go back five spaces.
If the pawn lands on a blue space, they have to go back to start.
If a player rolls the same number on both dice, they gain a fan token, which grants them extra movement in round three.
Since the game is about biathlon, there is also a shooting exercise that takes place after rounds one and two: Players have to hit a target with a wooden marble, using a wooden catapult. Generally, each player has five shots per round to hit the five targets, but shooting cards may allow them to reload. Each missed target means extra spaces to complete in a penalty round.

Explore the galaxy! Avoid Space Pirates! Move through Worm Holes! Watch out for Asteroids! Oh, and while you're at it, trade for resources and deliver them to the planets that need them.

Each Player is an independent space merchant captain jetting around the galaxy trying to collect resources to fill orders. There are 6 planets that need different resources, but each planet only sells one resource. Fill orders to make money and earn victory points. Once an order is filled, the planet has a new order. Earn additional victory points by exploring the board, but beware! The Galaxy is full of asteroids, worm holes and pirates that can will stand in your way.

The player with the most victory points at the end of the game wins!

The hex board is set up randomly for each game, so exploring the board is part of the fun! No two games will play quite the same. Who is the best space explorer and merchant captain?

Pixel Quest its a cooperative card game for 1 to 4 players, based on classic 8-bit RPGs. In this adventure game you will play as a party of heroes, travelling around to complete different quests. You’ll get an objective card at the start of the game: once the quests in it are complete, you’ll fight the final Boss. If you defeat him you’ll have won the game.

For each quest, you need to build a deck so your group of heroes can explore it. During these adventures the heroes will fight dangerous monsters, avoid deadly traps and find priceless treasures. But there is more than adventure in a hero’s life – they’ll also get rest at inns, drink at taverns and buy objects that will help them in future quests.

The greatest 8-bit RPG of all times, and you will not be playing it on a video game console, but on a table. Do you dare?

User Summary

The board game "poco a poco" is an excellent musical educational tool for any piano instructor. It is extremely versatile and can be used to facilitate learning in both group piano lessons and one-on-one piano lessons. It can be easily adapted for many or as few as two players, and the written board game "rules" are meant to broken if the needs of the class require the piano instructor to do so! The piano instructor must have these following items to actually play "poco a poco" successfully in conjunction with the board game itself: "one piano, metronome, basic technique, sight reading and ear training books/materials, manuscript paper or white board, and [little candies] or other treats." (Poco A Poco Game Rules, p. 1 poco a poco productions 1996)

Game play
Players or teams each roll die to move around the "keyboard" board, answering musical technique or term trivia and performing musical exercises in the varying categories required. Points or candies are awarded to players or teams who have completed their trivia or exercises successfully. The player or team who has the most points or candies is declared the winner.

Only a few hundred copies were produced and sold locally. Production ceased when the designers diverged.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

"Finishing races is important, but racing is more important." – Dale Earnhardt

Do you feel the need for speed? If so, Road Rally USA has you covered! Simply pressing the accelerator is not enough, as you must be efficient, managing your fuel and coming in first at your optimal checkpoints to maximize your score. Thus, you need to race and maneuver to be in the proper position when scoring your checkpoints.

Try as you might, it's impossible to maintain the lead throughout the race – and truth be told, while being first at the end of the race helps, placing first at your scoring locations is even more important. Every turn someone could trigger a scoring point. Where will you be as you and your opponents control which checkpoints will score and which get bypassed?

Each racer plays from identical draw decks, playing multiple cards of the same color to provide a boost of speed. Beware as you may reshuffle your deck only at gas stations along the way, and when your hand or draw pile are depleted, you are in for trouble. Race smart and bring home the gold!

item.description:
Hands in the Sea is a two-player deck building wargame on the First Punic War, between Rome and Carthage, 264–241 BC.

Each player has a starting deck of cards they use to perform various actions, up to two per round. Actions range from colonization, to naval movement, to battle, with most activity centered in and around Sicily and Sardinia/Corsica. Players may also purchase additional cards from their own custom decks, or from a set of neutral cards that either player may purchase. There are also Strategy cards that each player can purchase (one, max) that give the owning player some special advantage.

The game is played over the course of several turns, up to a maximum of twelve. At the end of each turn, players resolve random events, collect income and score victory points. There are several paths to victory, ranging from simply having the highest score at the end of the game, to capturing the opposing player's capital.

Inspired by A Few Acres of Snow, this game features several new elements, including navies, naval battles, cavalry superiority, mercenaries, field battles, sieges, manpower, strategy cards, random events, turn based scoring, bribery and tactical bonuses.

The name of the game is based on a quote from a Carthaginian commander, who claimed at the outbreak of hostilities that the Carthaginian control of the seas was such that the Romans would not even dare wash their hands in the sea.

item.description:
In his turn player has 30 seconds to answer questions in various topics. With each correct answer player advances 1 step on the track with his pawn.
Player who finishes first is the winner.

The objective is to reach opponent side of the game board diagonally first by playing maze-tiles and moving his pawn. 
In turn, player rolls the dice. 
If player rolls even numbers 2,4,6: He may advances his pawn two squares and can place or rotate a tile.
If player rolls odd numbers 1,3,5: He may place a tile and turn a tile.

Based on the same game concept as London: The Board Game, Wien! is a simple family game that lets the players explore the city, discovering the history of the Austrian capital. The board is divided into two areas: the city map and the Timeline. Moving on the city map, the players reach the most famous locations in town and collect historical cards that can then be played to advance on the Timeline. The first player to complete the path on the Timeline wins. Specific knowledge of the history of the town is not required to play the game because Wien! is not a trivia game.

Both player has equal number of Satellites on the game board.
In his turn player rolls the dice and moves his rocket on the game board. If he landed on opponent´s Satellite he takes it over and turns around his color face-up.
Player who owns all the satellites wins the game.

Based on the same game concept used in London: The Board Game, Polimi Timeline is dedicated to celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Politecnico di Milano (a.k.a. "Polimi"), one of the most prestigious Italian universities. Moving on a map representing the most important locations built or renovated by the architects who graduated at the Polimi, the players collect cards than can then be played to advance on the Timeline, discovering the history of the University. The first player to complete the path on the Timeline wins.

Based on the popular TV show "Horrible Histories", Awful Egyptians is set in ancient Egypt. The players are "rotten robbers" who try to steal the treasures of the dead Pharaoh hidden in the Pyramid in order to sell them to the rich men in the villages and the unlawful priests in the temples.

Objective: Be the first moving all your meeples into opposite corner (Halma variant for two on a small board)
 - moving by turns -
Playing equipment consists of a checkered board, divided into 7 x 7 squares. Pieces are typically red and blue; in two opposite corners of the board there are thirteen squares - starting area.

This is a Trivia game with questions about the kitchen. All questions have multiple choices.
Draw a card and ask! Who answers correctly scores a point.
Who has the most points is the winner.

200 cards, 13 topics: general culture, culinary knowledge, world cuisine, quotes, riddles recipes, fruits & vegetables, cheeses, confectionery, chocolate, wine & cocktails, coffee, tea, etc.

Cyvasse is a two-player strategy board game, featured in George R.R. Martin’s “A Song of Ice and Fire” series.

â€¨ Cyvasse features ten types of “unit” (King, Dragon, Elephant, Trebuchet, Catapult, Heavy Horse, Light Horse, Crossbowman, Spearman and Rabble) with different powers and attributes and capture conditions.
 In addition, the board includes individual "Mountain" and "Fortress" tiles, allowing for a different battlefield terrain each game 
 Before play, each player arranges their half of the board secretly, placing units and terrain tiles under cover of a large dividing screen. Once arranged, the screen is removed and play proceeds in alternating turns. Each piece has its own strengths and weaknesses, and multiple units (such as Elephants and Spearmen) may be moved during a single turn.
The game ends upon the capture of an opposing player’s King.

Cyvasse combines the simple elegance of chess with elements reminiscent "Stratego" and "Blitzkrieg".

The following material represents an amalgamation of the better fan-published material found online coupled with my own ideas.â€¨ It is hoped that the following interpretation provides a balanced, interesting and (above all) fun Cyvasse experience while keeping as close as possible to the descriptions presented in the novels.

item.description: Table Skittles is like bowling but the ball is attached to a chain which is swung in the air and makes no ground contact. Players take turns throwing the ball in a clockwise direction around the pole to knock down the pins. There are many different variants and rules because of the games age but the main game rule version played is the first player to knock down exactly 101 pins wins the game.

A speed game of card matching.

Opponents race to get rid of the cards in their hands by matching identical types of deadly animals. Once a match is made it is laid face up in front of you. Opponents will 'steal' the tricks in front of you if they have a matching card. The first person to lose all their cards shouts "Deadly Ruckus!", and gets a 5 point bonus for going out first. All players then gain 1 point for each card in front of them, and minus 1 for each card in their hand.

The process of stealing tricks from other players if you have a single matching card gives the game something of a fatal flaw in that slower players gain more cards in front of them.

name.value: Was ist Was: Das große Quiz

item.description:
Was ist Was: Das große Quiz is a combination board game/app facilitator, with players trying to answer questions on topics ranging from nature, wildlife and art to geography, history and culture. On a turn, the active player rolls a die and moves on the game board to see which topic she'll be quizzed on. Some locations show a bonus space, in which all players compete in one of five different app games, with the winner being the one who first:


 Recognizes the correct animal.
 Identifies the right sound.
 Determines which animal is heavier, which building is taller, or which vehicle is faster.
 Knows where to find a particular country.
 Excavates a dinosaur first.


(If you're playing without the app, the active player chooses one of the topics for the bonus question presented to all players.)

In the wonderful land of Arkadia, a very old king has no heir. He organizes a tournament to offer his throne to the bravest adventurer of the kingdom. Up to five finalists will wander seven worlds full of surprises...

In the drawing game Loony Quest, players study challenging level cards, then try to replicate the outline to meet targets and avoid obstacles on their tracing sheets. Once finished, players place their sheets on top of the level card to see whether the drawings line up with the targets they meant to hit — or avoid. Largely inspired by video games, Loony Quest players discover various worlds, play with 3D and 2D levels, run into loony monsters — Loonies — and big bosses, trigger special stages, collect bonuses, use penalties on opponents, and gather as many Xperience points as possible to win.

Loony Quest features the same basic gameplay as in Doodle Quest, but has been developed differently by the publisher.

item.description: Notwithstanding the title of this game – Versteck dich, kleine Schnecke! – the snail will not hide itself, but will instead need help from at least one of the players. Playable either indoors and out, this game of hide and seek has one player turning over a color chip, then hiding the game's snail in a location matching this color. The other players then work together to hunt down the snail, or chase it down individually to find it, salt it, and take a bite in triumph before anyone else can get their hands on it.

name.value: Der will nur spielen! Das Familienspiel

item.description:
In Der will nur Spielen! Das Familienspiel, players compete in a wide variety of categories, each testing their animal knowledge or reflexes in varied ways. Who has a good reaction time when retrieving something? Who can remember the most signals? Who can dig out a bone hidden in a bed of roses? Who knows the favorite breeds of the other players? And who can show off her knowledge of dog breeds by answering questions?

For all of these activities and more, players are rewarded with bones when they do well, and whoever first collects twenty bones in her basket wins!

from the designer:

"The basic idea is simple: players take turns placing stones on a board, forming groups. When the board is full, each players calculates the product of the sizes of his two largest groups. Whoever has the larger number wins."

A Real Trivia Challenge! Matter of Fact is perfect for those who know a lot - or think they do... Every game card has seven questions for you to answer around a main theme. The more questions you answer correctly, the more spaces you move along the board. Stumble too much and you might even have to move backwards. The Answer Tracker shows how well you’re doing. All subjects are covered in a variety of fun formats: from Claim to Fame, Title Twist, All Mixed Up, and more. Just go down the Question List and see how you do, either on your own or with the help of teammates. It’s trivia with a whole new twist!

YOU'LL NEVER GUESS! (...or will you?) Stimulate your brain, challenge your skills of deduction, and have fun trying to guess what players are up to! Say the Presenter reads out a question like ‘Where Am I?’. It could be Dallas, France, Hawaii or somewhere else. So how will you figure out where they’re pretending to be? By asking them your own questions to narrow down the possibilities. You could ask: ‘Would I take a plane to get there?’, ‘Is it a city?’, ‘Does it have cold winters?’, or anything else you can think of. You decide what to ask. You may also get to roll for a Letter Clue. In another round you might be asked to guess what someone's supposed to be ‘wearing’, ‘eating’, ‘holding’, and much more.

Not to be confused with "Characters from Charles Dickens," this is a card game from circa 1889. There are 37 cards in six sets of six, plus one Dickens card. Each set consists of a book card (Pickwick Papers, Oliver Twist, Nicholas Nickleby, Old Curiosity Shop, Barnaby Rudge, and David Copperfield) and 5 character cards.
Players ask each other for needed cards to complete a set, with the Dickens card doubling the value.

Milton Bradley also produced a facsimile edition in 1970.

In this abstract strategy game, each turn you add a tile to the table matching up at least one section with the previously laid tiles. Each section on the outer perimeter is worth a point so try to surround your opponents tiles to reduce their score, or try to create an enclosed area where scores are doubled. Place your tiles carefully, to out maneuver your opponents, and get the highest score in Polygon!

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

It's time to save time! The hourglasses shown on the Professor Tempus cards are what make them valuable: The player who has the most hourglasses at the end of the game wins.

Three sets of cards are played simultaneously in ascending or descending order. At the end of each round, the cards in each set are kept by the player who last laid a card on that set. Play your hand carefully, though, because the sets change hands constantly. Professor Tempus is a super-dynamic and very interactive game.

item.description:
This game is a take on Oneonta Whist for 2-7 players. Like in Oneonta Whist, this game involves precise bidding, and can be played with 2 players and also cooperatively for up to 7 players. Variant rules for solitaire play are included, but the nature of dominoes makes the solitaire play not as good as that in regular Oneonta Whist.

The Domino part of the name comes from the game use dominoes or a deck of playing cards that are dominoes. In this a player would end up leading with a card, and announce which of the two sides is the suit, and the other side is the value in the suit. Players would follow the same.

The trump suit is determined by flipping over one of the no pip cards.

In addition, players can bid to take as many tricks as they can take, and lose what they bid if they fail to make it, or make what they bid if they make as many tricks as the bid, and lose one point for each trick more.

The baiting game!

In Fish Fish, a game of bluff and betting, you will alternate between playing the fisherman and the fish. In each round, the fisherman cast five lines. Only two of them actually catch fish – but which ones? The fish must be cunning to earn points without getting caught, and the fisherman need to be smart enough to get the fish to take the bait!

item.description:
The eggs are done!

The aim of Ovo is to get all of your eggs back home after they've been flipped over in your opponent's camp. On the way to that camp, the players' symbols on each egg are visible – 
but on the way back those symbols are hidden so that the eggs, which can be moved by any player, are no longer identifiable. Since nothing looks more like an egg than another egg, your challenge is to keep track of your eggs as they hop, skip and jump their way home!

The year is 1931. In a suburb of the city of Chicago, prohibition is in full bloom and honest people violate more and more laws. Gangster syndicates spread and become larger, and speakeasies open in dark alleys. This illegal activity has now spread out to the smaller suburbs. It's now your turn to make the best of the situation for your family's sake. Will you become a gangster king, or do you think the stock market will go up after the great stock market crash a few years ago so that you will become a wealthy businessman?

Gangsters and upper class people will clash in this board game. Will money win over weapons, or it will be the opposite? Form alliances with your neighbors, build up your arsenal of money or weapons, and let the game run its course.

In Suburban Dispute you fight your neighbors for the simple reason that you don't like them. The game includes three levels, starting quietly with annoying missions like stealing your neighbor's morning paper or milk, but each level you go up, the worse it gets. In the end, you will be conducting drive-by shootings and burning down your neighbors' houses.

The game board features a street down the middle, in addition to the score board, and each player places his house next to the street, with a maximum of three neighbors on each side of the street. The players can choose to be either gangsters or members of the upper class before the game starts, and based on what they choose, they receive specific traits that will help them through the gameplay.

Players then take turns drawing special mission cards and rolling a die in order to see whether they succeed with the mission. If the missions succeed, players gain either money or points, depending on the mission level; if the mission fails, then the police come to arrest them, and they lose either points or money, depending on the mission level. During gameplay, players also have the option of drawing special cards specific for gangster and the upper class which will, in most cases, be helpful in order to get closer to the end goal, which is to either collect 60 points, earn 15,000, or be the last player standing.

name.value: Quizfächer Mein kleiner Brockhaus Die Tiere

item.description:
A quiz in the form of a fan, on the subject of general knowledge - 'primary school level' -, questions and answers about animals sequenced by different biospheres: garden, forest, farm, savanna, jungle, ocean. The cards are held by a screw and can be ideally taken on travels, the answers are always on the next page. The quiz can be played alone or by several players.
 - 54 pages; 53 different animals -
 - acting simultaneously/by turns -
active player reads aloud a question with 3 given answers (multiple choice, solutions at the following page); all players guess correct answer(s) & collecting points. Typically there are more questions (~3) on one page.

In Ancient Terrible Things, a pulp horror adventure game for 2-4 players, you play the role of an intrepid adventurer, exploring a dark jungle river. Each turn you must travel to a Fateful Location, face an Ominous Encounter, and attempt to unlock its Ancient Secrets. If you succeed (using a combination of dice, tokens and cards), you add the Secrets to your score; if you fail, you unleash a Terrible Thing, which counts against your score at the end of the game. The object of the game is to be the player with the most Ancient Secrets when the game ends at the Unspeakable Event.

Game play involves rolling dice to achieve combinations: runs, pairs, three or more of a kind, and single die showing a particular number or higher. Dice combos are used to overcome Encounter cards that are worth points at the end of the game, and/or to acquire the four resource tokens in the game: Focus, Courage, Treasure and Feat.


 Focus tokens are used to re-roll individual dice. 
 Courage tokens are spent to overcome an Encounter, before rolling your dice. 
 Treasure tokens are spent to purchase Swag cards from the Trading Post, which give you a permanent game effect.
 Feat tokens are spent to play Feat cards from your hand, which activate one-shot effects.

name.value: A Race to Rescue Snow White

item.description:
A straightforward dice game in the tradition of Goose games. Move along the track according to die roll. Obey instructions should you land on a special square (Red - bad, Blue - good).Throw an exact number to get into the castle and rescue Snow White.

This appeared in The Walt Disney Treasure Book, published by Odhams Press, circa 1960 I would guess. Look at the nice way the publisher has chosen to remind readers that you will need counters, a die and a dice shaker before you can start the game.

quroma is an abstact game played on a 4×4 grid.
48 squares in 12 different colors are randomly placed on the grid (3 on each space)
Then, each turn, you have 3 actions points that you must use. Select a square, then use the action points to flip its stack over, or to move the top square in its stack to an adjacent space, or any combination along the way.

Furthermore, on your turn, the square you select must be the same color as revealed by the prevous player's first action. If the previous player's first action revealed the table, then you can select any square for your move (just like at the start of the game).

If you have stacked two squares of the same color at the end of your third action, you collect these squares, removing them from play.

As soon as there are only single squares left (no more stacks), the game is over. The player with the most quartets (4 squares of the same color) is the winner. If there is a tie, the player with the most pairs wins.

Objective: be the first surrounding the map - learn traffic signs

- moving by turns -
Roll the die & move your meeple clockwise around the map; if your move ends on a traffic sign follow instructions printed inside the lid. You may take another route across the map, but you may turn left only entering a junction.

remarks;
at least 5 different editions, very first before WWII

name.value: El Alamein: Turning Point in the Desert

item.description:
"El Alamein" is a two-player operational wargame simulating the 2nd Battle of El Alamein from 23 October – 11 November, 1942.

One player commands the attacking Allied forces (British, Commonwealth, Free French and Greek) while the other player commands the defending Axis forces (German and Italian). Each hex measures 5km across, unit scale is brigade, regimental and battalion, and most turns represent two days of combat.

The game consists of eight turns and each turn has four impulses. During each impulse the Allied player may perform actions with his units and then the Axis player. In each impulse, players choose to move, combat, or pass. Players use dice rolling and CRT to determine the combat result. If at the end of any impulse the Sidi Abd el Rahman and the Tel el Acqqaqir are both Allied-controlled the game ends immediately in an automatic Allied victory.

In Pets, players want to collect animals – but only if they'll score points during the game's three scoring rounds.

The card deck includes 105 cards showing seven types of animals, with the animals numbered 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21 and 24; this number indicates how many of that type of card are in the deck. Each player starts with seven cards in hand, and three rows of ten face-up cards are placed on the table. On a turn, a player takes one of three actions:


 Play cards from his hand onto the table. You can play only one type of animal, you cannot already own this type, and you must play more than are shown by an opponent. The opponents cards of this type must then be placed onto the deposit pile. 
 Pick up cards from a row. You take all the cards of a single type from either end of any row and add them to your hand, then place the card in the row adjacent to these cards (and all cards of the same type) in the scoring area.
 Place one card from your hand at the end of a row.


If a row is emptied, create a new row of ten cards from the deck. As soon as six cards of the same type are in the scoring area, players score points for their holdings. If you hold some number of "24" cards, for example, you score a number of points equal to the number of 24 cards in the scoring area; if you score for two, three, or more types of cards, then your total score for the round doubles, triples, etc.

After scoring, shuffle all cards from the deposit pile, scoring cards and all cards players have played, then place them under the deck. After the third scoring, players tally their points and see who wins.

(Gauner accommodates 2-4 players instead of 2-5.)

item.description:
In Tegulis Romanis, players play as the influential families who built Rome from the ground up, working to build Rome into a glorious metropolis.

During the game, the players will lay tiles onto the random boards which make up the landscape on which Rome was built. Each tile shows a building, which will belong to the player when played on the board but is not considered "built" until it has its required resources. Resources are on the back-side of the buildings (the players must decide which buildings to not play so they can place resources), but resources on the board have no "owner" so they can be used by buildings belonging to any player. Once a building has its resources it is now "built" and gains the owner points or special abilities (the player may now build in the mountains, the player draws extra tiles, etc.).

The players each have the same starting pile of tiles, with another set of "advanced tiles" available to any player, most of which actually require other buildings as "resources" themselves.

Object of the game:
Be the first arriving at target field

Simple 'Roll and Move' game, learning the cities & places of interest of Switzerland.
Equipped with four plastic meeples, die and playing board.
Follow instructions (lid inside) if move ends on a marked field.

Each player takes on the role of one or perhaps a handful of Wild West characters in a variety of situations--bank robberies, claims jumps, wagon train raids, etc. Each situation will take place on a map that is hand-drawn and divided into irregularly shaped zones.

Players roll dice to determine their action point allowance, which they then spend to perform actions like moving, shooting, reloading, etc.

When a player wants to shoot at another player, he or she has to try to guess the suit of a card drawn from a normal deck of playing cards.

If the guess is right, the shot hits and inflicts damage unique to its suit/value/weapon used. If the guess is wrong, the shot misses. Certain character traits and conditions of the shot can increase or decrease the number of suits the player is allowed to guess.

Scenarium is an improvisational storytelling game for 4-20 people who can play as individuals or as teams of two. It is a party game where players act, draw, and tell stories based on interesting prompts and creative commons photos.

Scenarium was successfully funded on Kickstarter in 2014.

The game mechanic is similar to Apples to Apples or Cards Against Humanity. The game begins with one of the players/teams in the role of The Director. The Director chooses a card and a prompt (Tell, Draw, or Act) and all the other players/teams of two have a few seconds to prepare before telling, drawing, or acting out their response. The best performance, in the eyes of The Director wins the card, and then the player or team to the Director's left becomes the next Director. The first player or team to five cards wins.

It's an easy game to learn - the directions fit on one side of a playing card, and it's a flexible game that encourages house rules (all acting, family and kids versions, drinking game versions, etc.). Each game takes about 30-45 minutes to play.

There are 249 game cards in the limited edition version of Scenarium, and each card has three prompts. The average game only takes 12-18 rounds so you'll never see the same game twice.

The company gives a portion of their proceeds to CrashCourse and Kiva.org.

Sky Thieves is a steampunk card game. You play as the captain of an airship full of pirates, with the goal of being the first captain to steal 5 treasure. To steal treasure, you have to battle targets like an Iron Automaton, a Fortified Depository, or the Military Police. You can arm your ship with crazy technology like an Astral Tracking System, Semiautonomous Exosuit, or (the old classic) a Death Ray. When your opponents are trying to steal a treasure you'd rather take, you can sabotage them with a Planted Mutineer or some Drugged Rum.

Play is easy to learn, like Munchkin, with strategic depth to keep things interesting, like Race for the Galaxy.

item.description:
The Witches: A Discworld Game is the second of three games by Martin Wallace set in Terry Pratchett's Discworld, the first being Discworld: Ankh-Morpork.

The Witches is set in the magically charged land of Lancre. Players take on the role of trainee witches, such as Tiffany Aching and Petulia Gristle, learning their craft and dealing with all the problems, both petty and serious, that life on Discworld can throw at them. A subtle blend of headology, magic and, of course, the all-important cup of tea will see our heroines tackle everything from a sick pig to a full-blown invasion of elves. Each player tries to be better at everything than the others, while also cooperating to prevent crises from escalating.

Life can be tough for a young witch in Lancre. Fear not, however, as some of Terry Pratchett's most famous characters will be on hand to aid your quest. Along the way you'll meet Granny Weatherwax, Nanny Ogg and Magrat Garlick, as well as a rich supporting cast of familiar faces from the Discworld series. When things get really tough and you feel you are turning "Black Aliss", you can always have a cup of tea with one of your fellow witches.

The Witches can be played competitively, cooperatively, or solo.

item.description:
Operational level wargame for the battle of Tabaruzaka in Satsuma Rebellion. Gekitoh means fierce battle, and Tabaruzaka was most important pass in the battle.

Players control either Imperial Japanese Army or Rebel Force of Satsuma Domain, and manage military operations. The main engine use chit-pull activation and leader counters play an important role.

Winner determined by control of important places on the map.

This game was published(and printed) in pages of Japanese Tactics Magazine Renewal Nr.3, and separate components are not provided.

Objective: be the first reaching target zone with all (5) your meeples
 - moving by turns -
'three-dimensional' Halma with possibility to bounce your opponents - 
1.) three-dimensional board is plugged first
2.) 2-player game: each player chooses one side/4-player-game: 2 players use one side each
3.) move your meeples according Halma rules climbing vertically
(plug in)
4.) an opponent's meeple (on reverse side) will be bounced if another meeple ends on that space (circled spaces are safe - can't be reached)
5.) game ends after all 5 meeples reached target zone

should be published during end 1950's
tower is about 12" high

Objective:
be the first finishing your round trip
 - moving by turns -
Each player chooses her/his own (coloured) route:
simple 'roll & move' game; ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on lid inside.

remarks: 
published during 1950's - plastic (painted) meeples:
republished 1960's as 'Reise durch die Welt' - but rules and board stayed unchanged (old title); facts (like inhabitants...) are related to the 50's.

From the publisher:
"Charlie Wesencraft's Book is a real classic from the early days of the growth of the hobby. It developed the ideas of Donald Featherstone and others with the aim of making a more realistic wargame. It contained a straightforward set of 'common' rules then modified them for the different periods. The book has rules seven sets of rules from ancients to the Franco Prussian War."

objective: be the first reaching target space 
 - moving by turns -
simple 'roll & move' game: ending on a marked space follow instructions;

Object of the game:
Be the first arriving at target space (Munich)

Simple 'Roll and Move' game, learning the cities & places of interest of Bavaria.
Equipped with large painted plastic pawns, die and playing board.
meeples: traditional 'rambling club' dress
